metadata.title: Exfoliated β-Ga2O3 nano-belt field-effect transistors for air-stable high power and high temperature electronics

sections.text:
This study demonstrated the exfoliation of two-dimensional (2D) β-Ga2O3 nano-belt
and subsequent processing into a thin film transistor structure. This mechanical exfoliation and transfer method produce β-Ga2O3 nano-belts with a pristine surface as well as a continuous defect-free interface with the SiO2/Si substrate. This β-Ga2O3 nano-belt based transistor displayed an on/off ratio that increased from approximately 104 to 107 over the operating temperature range of 20 °C to 250 °C. No electrical breakdown was observed in
our measurements up to VDS=+40 V and VGS=−60 V between 25 °C to 250 °C. Additionally, the electrical characteristics were not degraded after a month-long storage in an air ambient. The demonstration of high-temperature / high-voltage operation of quasi-2D β-Ga2O3 nanobelts contrasts with traditional 2D material such as transition metal dichalcogenides that intrinsically have limited temperature and power operational envelopes owing to their narrow bandgap. This work motivates the application of 2D β-Ga2O3 to high power nano-electronic devices for harsh environments such as high temperature chemical sensors and

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The discovery of graphene opened the door to the electronic, optical and mechanical
applications of two-dimensional (2D) crystals1. Graphene, which is the most investigated material among 2D materials, has Dirac cone structure with zero energy band-gap2,3, which unfortunately makes it undesirable for channel layer of conventional active electronic devices including field-effect transistors and diodes4. In contrast, the transition metal dichalcogenides(TMDs) generally possess a non-zero bandgap in its 2D form5. In particular, WSe26 and MoS27 are emerging as attractive candidates for the study of fundamental physics in 2D and in layered (thin-film) structures as they show superior properties over their bulk counterparts. However, the band-gap of most TMDs is limited to approximately 1 eV due to their symmetry. Until now, nanoscale materials such as nanotubes8, graphene9, and TMDs10,11 have been actively studied for low-power and room/low temperature electronic switching applications. The small band-gap of these materials has precluded the use of these nanodevices for high power and high temperature applications.
This current work focused on β-Ga2O3, which is a thermally and chemically stable,
wide band-gap (approximately 4.9 eV) semiconductor material12,13. According to its estimated high breakdown electric field (approximately 8 MV/cm), β-Ga2O3 based devices have huge potential for high-power electronic switching applications14. Bulk or epitaxiallygrown β-Ga2O3 crystals have been fabricated into metal-semiconductor field-effect transistors (MESFETs)15, depletion-mode metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs)16 and Schottky barrier diodes17 for the utilizations in power electronic devices. Though β-Ga2O3 is not a van der Waals 2D material similar to graphene, black phosphorus or MoS2, the monoclinic structure of bulk β-Ga2O3 crystal allows relatively simple cleavage into ultra-thin flakes in the (100) direction18,19.

In this study, thin flakes were mechanically exfoliated from bulk β-Ga2O3 crystal
using the scotch tape method. The exfoliation process was repeated to obtain ultra-thin flakes (or nano-belts), which were fabricated into the back-gated field-effect transistors (FETs) using a conventional photolithography process. Owing to its wide band-gap of approximately 4.9 eV, the ultra-thin β-Ga2O3 nanobelt thin film transistors (TFT) are inherently more electrically and thermally stable than other 2D-material based TFTs. Remarkably, the electrical properties, including the field-effect carrier mobility, on/off ratio, transconductance and output power, improved with increasing temperature up to 250°C. The stability of the Ga2O3 surface did not necessitate a surface protection / passivation layer (e.g., Al2O3 or SiO2) in this study. We demonstrated exfoliated β-Ga2O3 nano-belt based TFTs and systematically analyzed the electrical characteristics of the fabricated 2D β-Ga2O3 devices at the elevated temperatures and after a month-long storage in an air ambient.

sections.heading: Experimental details
sections.text:
Bulk β-Ga2O3 crystal with (-201) surface orientation (Tamura Corp., Japan) was
grown by the edge-defined film-fed growth method and unintentionally n-doped with an effective carrier density (Nd-Na) of approximately 3 × 1017 cm−3. The atomic arrangement in monoclinic β-Ga2O3 allows a facile cleavage into thin flakes along the (100) direction, which has a larger lattice constant than other primary directions (a [100] = 12.225 Å and b [010] =
3.039 Å, c [001] = 5.801 Å)20. Nano-scale thickness β-Ga2O3 flakes were separated from
bulk β-Ga2O3 crystal by repeated application of the mechanical exfoliation technique with commercial Scotch tape, which is similar to the graphene exfoliation from highly oriented pyrolytic graphite. A schematic of the fabrication process is shown in Fig. 1. The

mechanically exfoliated nano-belt was transferred to a SiO2 / p+ Si (300 nm/500 μm) substrate. Prior to the transfer, a back-gate Ti/Au (20 nm/80 nm) electrode was deposited by an electron beam evaporator onto the opposing face of the substrate. The β-Ga2O3 nano-belt was processed into a back-gate FET via a conventional photolithography process consisting of metallization by electron beam evaporation and lift-off process. The source and drain electrodes were defined by a Ti/Au (20 nm/80 nm) metallization with a source to drain electrode spacing of 8 µm.
Micro-Raman spectroscopy at room temperature was carried out in a back-scattering
geometry with the 532 nm line of a diode-pumped solid state laser (Omicron) to analyze the structural properties of the β-Ga2O3 nano-belts. The surface morphology of β-Ga2O3 nanobelts was studied via atomic force microscopy (AFM) (XE100, PSIA) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (S4700, Hitachi). Atomic structure and crystal orientations were investigated via transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (G2 F30ST, Tecnai). The specimen was prepared by using focused ion beam equipment (FIB, Quanta2003D, FEI). To protect the surface of the samples from Ga-ion bombardments during the FIB fabrication, an additional carbon layer was deposited above the β-Ga2O3 nano-belts. The current-voltage (I-V) and transport characteristics of the β-Ga2O3 nano-belt FET were obtained at various operating temperatures, ranging from 25 °C to 250 °C using an Agilent 4155C semiconductor parameter analyzer connected to the probe station equipped with hot plate. Due to the thermal annealing effects on the electrodes, I-V characteristics were obtained with decreasing temperature from 250 °C to 25 °C.

The morphology and thickness of the exfoliated and subsequently transferred β-
Ga2O3 nano-belt were evaluated with AFM and SEM. Figure 2(a) shows the AFM image of β-Ga2O3 nano-belt fabricated into the TFT structure with two Ti/Au electrodes. The bulk βGa2O3 crystal was exfoliated into an extremely planar flake with a thickness of approximately 200 nm. This demonstrates that the mechanical exfoliation technique commonly applied to van der Waals materials is also applicable to the monoclinic β-Ga2O3 crystal. As shown in the electron micrographs of figs. 2(c) and 2(d), the exfoliated β-Ga2O3 flakes is composed of layered structure, which could theoretically be further exfoliated to few- or bi-layers, or even a mono-layer film. A layered structure with triangular edges after the mechanical exfoliations is observable in figure 2(d).
The quality of the exfoliated β-Ga2O3 nano-belt was compared with that of bulk β-
Ga2O3 using a micro-Raman spectroscopy. There was no significant change in the phonon positions as shown in figs. 3(a) and 3(b),21,22 indicating that the quality of the transferred βGa2O3 ultra-thin flakes was not degraded during exfoliation and the optical lithography process. The difference in base lines is attributed to the silicon substrate beneath β-Ga2O3 nano-belt. In order to further analyze the structural properties of the exfoliated β-Ga2O3 flakes, a cross-sectional TEM image was obtained for a β-Ga2O3 nano-belt, which was transferred onto a SiO2/Si substrate. There are no obvious deformations in the β-Ga2O3 crystal. Additionally, there are no observable faults in the interface between β-Ga2O3 ultrathin flake and SiO2/Si substrate, confirming a van der Waals bonding arrangement in this heterostructure. One of the advantages of the exfoliation and subsequent transfer on the target substrates is the absence of the strain in heterostructure as shown in high resolution TEM image (figure 3(d)). The exfoliated β-Ga2O3 flake appears defect-free, and no strain or damage was induced by the transfer and subsequent device fabrication processes. Note that

The selected area electron diffraction pattern of this sample is shown in figure 3(e), revealing the lattice symmetry and the lattice parameters of the exfoliated β-Ga2O3 thin flake. The pattern corresponds to a d-spacing of approximately 0.61 nm and a diffraction pattern of the (200) lattice plane, which confirmed that the β-Ga2O3 thin flake is exfoliated in the [100] a-direction20,23. Further investigation is underway to obtain mono- or bi-layers of exfoliated β-Ga2O3.
Figure 4(a) shows the IDS-VDS (source-drain current versus source-drain voltage)
characteristics of the β-Ga2O3 micro-belt TFTs at the elevated operating temperatures. The IDS was effectively modulated by the gate-source voltage (VGS) with good saturation and sharp pinch-off characteristics, indicating that the channel layer is an n-type semiconductor. The ntype conductivity is attributable to oxygen vacancies and impurities that act as an electrondonor in the Ga2O3 crystal24,25. No electrical breakdown was observed in our measurements up to VDS=+40 V and VGS=−60 V between 25 °C to 250 °C. This indicates that the nanodevices made of β-Ga2O3 nano-belts can deliver high power at the elevated temperatures, which has not been demonstrated in 2D material-based devices. The electrical characteristics of the fabricated FET were maintained well in the high temperature ranging up to 250 °C. Figure 4(b) illustrates the temperature-dependent transfer characteristics of the fabricated βGa2O3 nano-belt FET at VDS=+20 V. The electrical properties including transconductance and output currents were improved with increasing operating temperature. No hysteresis on both the forward and reverse gate bias sweeps was observed, which indicates the clean interface between the exfoliated β-Ga2O3 nano-belt and the SiO2 layer. Also, the surface between the exfoliated β-Ga2O3 nano-belt and the air ambient did not display visual degradation at the elevated temperatures. The on/off ratio, defined as the IDS at VGS = 0 V divided by the IDS at VGS = −60 V
increased from approximately 104 to approximately 107 in the operating temperature range from 20 °C to 250 °C (fig. 6(a)). As shown in fig. 6(b), the electrical conductance of β-Ga2O3 nano-belt rose with increasing the temperature. The increased electrical conductivity at the elevated temperatures is consistent with the previous reports in β-Ga2O324-26. The activation energy estimated by using an Arrhenius plot was approximately 0.25 eV for electrical conductivity as a function of temperature ranging from 25 °C to 250 °C, implying that the increased conductivity of β-Ga2O3 nano-belt was caused by the activation of oxygen vacancies in deep donor levels at higher temperature25,26. sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
In conclusion, β-Ga2O3 nano-belts with a [100] orientation were obtained from a bulk
β-Ga2O3 crystal using a mechanical exfoliation technique without degrading its quality. Outstanding electrical properties were obtained and maintained up to 250 °C. The β-Ga2O3 nano-belt FET displayed an on/off ratio of approximately 104 at room temperature and increased three orders of magnitude for operation at 250 °C. No electrical breakdown was
observed in our measurements up to VDS=+40 V and VGS=−60 V between 25 °C to 250 °C. This work motivates 2D β-Ga2O3 as a future nano-scale building block for high power and high temperature devices.
